results.title: The Event of the political party
results.creator_credit: Gwynn Pritchard, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: One of four films in the “Mass communications and society” series forming a case study on British politics and television, shot during the 1976 Labour and Conservative Party conferences held in Blackpool and Brighton respectively. Concentrates on the live broadcasts of the events of each day and reveals the philosophies that guide the broadcasters in their decision making. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Main control
results.creator_credit: Jon Miller, British Broadcasting Corporation and Open University

Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Mass communications and society: a mirror held up to reality
results.creator_credit: John Miller, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: First in a series of four films shot in Kansas City in August 1976, showing the ABC’s television coverage of the Republican Convention. The key areas are shown and the main figures explain their role and attitude towards the politicians and towards their competitors in the other networks. Also shown are the final editorial briefing and the production meeting, as well as the arrivals and speeches of Ronald Reagan and President ford.

results.title: Saturday night again
results.creator_credit: Jan Sharp, Richard Davis and Laughing Kookaburra Productions
results.brief_description: Looks at situations that could result in drink-driving, and also looks at the other options available through following the social life of a young Sydney group of friends made up of four males and one female in their late teens to early twenties. Covers willingness to intervene in a drink-driving situation; ability to say “no” to someone who wants to drive when he or she is unfit to do so; and alternative ways of spending an evening socialising without the risk of drink-driving. Features Gia Carrides. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Let there be light
results.creator_credit: John Huston and Department of Defense
results.brief_description: Produced by the American Department of Defence and banned for 35 years, this documentary deals with the treatment of soldiers suffering from war-induced psychotic and psychosomatic disorders. The camera records a wide range of emotional disabilities among the returning World War II veterans at Mason General Hospital at Long Island. Looks at the various methods of treatment which include hypnosis and truth-inducing drugs. The original purpose of the film was to convince the public, employers in particular, that soldiers suffering from neuro-psychiatric damage could be rehabilitated and resume civilian life. After seeing the finished product, the War Department withdrew the film for various reasons among them the invasion of the patients’ privacy and the fear that it would scare off potential recruit. Narrated by Walter Huston. Cinematography by Stanley Cortez.

results.title: Guinea pigs is pigs
results.brief_description: Entertaining treatment of bureaucracy at its worst, based on the short story “pigs is pigs” by Ellis parker Butler. A stationmaster, who goes by the rules and insists that “guinea pigs is pigs” and therefore must travel at a higher freight rate than domestic animals, is left to content with a rapidly expanding guinea pig populations and the pater warfare of the railway administration.
